newsitem.title: UK: UK housing market recovery continues, survey shows.
newsitem.headline: UK housing market recovery continues, survey shows.

text.p: The UK housing market enjoyed a better performance in October than in September for the first time since 1982, according to the latest survey of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS) said.
October showed the 14th consecutive month-on-month increase in the proportion of chartered surveyors reporting price increases, prompted by the shortage of properties for sale.

"Many potential vendors are waiting for higher prices in 1997, while would-be purchasers become increasingly frustrated by the lack of choice. There are reports of panic buying in some areas," said RICS housing market spokesman Ian Perry.
A net balance of 44 percent of chartered surveyors reported rising prices across England and Wales for the three months to the end of October.

The survey said the market imbalance was fuelled by a general rise in demand, a rush to beat the deadline on attractive fixed-rate mortgage offers and more people wanting to buy houses rather than rent.

Perry said a more properties were expected on the market in the New Year, which would tend to temper price rises. "The "wait and see' attitude of potential vendors has caused a bottleneck of demand. We expect this to ease next year," he added.
